Alicyclobacillus vulcanalis is a species of thermophilic, acidophilic bacteria that belongs to the genus Alicyclobacillus. This species was first isolated from a volcanic hot spring in Japan.

Alicyclobacillus vulcanalis is a Gram-positive, spore-forming, and rod-shaped bacterium. It is capable of growing at temperatures ranging from 45°C to 65°C, with an optimal growth temperature around 55°C. This species can tolerate acidic conditions, with a pH range for growth between 2.5 and 6.0, and an optimal pH around 4.0.

The unique feature of Alicyclobacillus vulcanalis is the presence of omega-alicyclic fatty acids in its cell membrane, which help the bacterium adapt to the high-temperature and acidic environments it inhabits. This adaptation allows the species to thrive in harsh, geothermal ecosystems, such as volcanic hot springs and acidic soils.

Alicyclobacillus vulcanalis is considered an important species in the field of food microbiology, as it can cause spoilage in acidic fruit juices and other food products, leading to off-flavors and discoloration. Understanding the physiology and growth characteristics of this thermoacidophilic bacterium is crucial for the development of effective food preservation and processing strategies.
